This is really interesting and cool.  No source available?  Could you talk a
little more (at a technical level) about how this works?  Is source
available on request?

Anyway, it looks to me like the use of dynamic proxies allows you to create
an object instance from a interface definition.  And then you've added the
ability to modify the state of the object, or at least mimic the behavior of
an object via your MockController.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia

> Hello all,
> 
> currently I am working on EasyMock, a mock object package for java
> that allows you to define simple mock objects for an interface 
> directly into your test code.
> 
> You will not need to write a mock class.
> 
> Example usage for defining a mock for HttpServletRequest
> that answers "EasyMock" to getParameter("page"):
>     MockController controller = new 
> MockController(HttpServletRequest.class);
>     HttpServletRequest mock = (HttpServletRequest) 
> controller.getMock();
> 
>     // Define the mock behaviour
>     mock.getParameter("page");
>     controller.setReturnValue("EasyMock");
> 
>     // activate the mock
>     controller.activate();
> 
>     // Use your mock here!
> A first version of the package is available at
> http://www.offis.de/projekte/xp/project_extremeprogramming.htm .
> Just follow the link to the preliminary EasyMock home page.
> 
> As EasyMock uses Proxies internally,
> it does only work with java version 1.3 and higher.
>
